definition: Han ethnic group/Chinese (language)/the Han dynasty (206 BC-220 AD)

home/family/(polite) my (sister, uncle etc)/classifier for families or businesses/refers to the philosophical schools of pre-Han China/noun suffix for a specialist in some activity, such as a musician or revolutionary, corresponding to English -ist, -er, -ary or -ian/CL:個|个[ge4]

sentences.english: This book is one of the most important ones in the research of Confucius Analects by the Qing sinologists.
sentences.chinese: 《论语考异》是清代汉学家研究《论语》的扛鼎之作。

sentences.english: Many directors of the Confucius Institutes are also Sinologists.
sentences.chinese: 许多孔子学院的院长就是汉学家。

sentences.english: Yang Yuanhong to direct the poetry. and sinologist Bunn TON.
sentences.chinese: 与汉学家霍布恩先生切磋。

sentences.english: Malmqvist is the sole sinologist among the eighteen members of the Swedish Academy .
sentences.chinese: 马悦然是瑞典皇家学院十八位院士中唯一的汉学家。

sentences.english: As a sinologist, Stephen Owen is famous for his works on classical Chinese literature.
sentences.chinese: 宇文所安是以中国古典文学研究而闻名的汉学家。

sentences.english: The thesis penetrates into the translation principles and the translations of the three British sinologists.
sentences.chinese: 本文重点探讨三位英国汉学家的译学与译作。

sentences.english: The thesis begins with a basic introduction to the three sinologists.
sentences.chinese: 本文先介绍三位汉学家的基本情况。

definition: sinology/Chinese studies (in foreign schools)/Han Learning, a Qing dynasty movement aiming at a philological appraisal of the Classics
Jonathan D Spence (1936-), distinguished British US historian of China, author of The search for modern China 追尋現代中國|追寻现代中国
Bernhard Karlgren (1889-1978), distinguished Swedish linguist and sinologist
Joseph Needham (1900-1995), British biochemist and author of Science and Civilization in China
a Jesuit/member of Society of Jesus
Gao Luopei or R.H. van Gulik (1910-1967), Dutch sinologist, diplomat and writer
James Legge (1815-1897), Scottish Protestant missionary in Qing China and translator of the Chinese classics into English
William A.P. Martin (1827-1916), American missionary who lived 62 years in China between 1850 and 1916, and helped found many Chinese colleges, first president of Peking University
